Key Arguments: The Bill grants ACMA substantial, unilateral, and discretionary authority, which threatens freedom of speech and expression.
The Bill is poorly drafted with vague definitions of key terms like 'misinformation', 'disinformation', and 'serious harm', making it prone to misuse.
The Bill's powers could lead to censorship and stifle scientific debate, as it allows ACMA to create enforceable rules without proper oversight.
The Bill imposes unacceptable restrictions on individuals who post content online, potentially subjecting them to civil and criminal penalties.
The Bill allows ACMA quasi-judicial powers that could infringe on privacy and other legal protections.
Notable Quotes: The Bill, if passed in its current form, would allow the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) substantial, unilateral and discretionary authority to govern all forms of media save those explicitly excepted from the Bill’s operation.
It is a flagrant dismissal of the rights to freedom of speech and expression Australia has covenanted into protecting.
The Bill is, contrary to Lord Hoffman’s well-known judgment, and as outlined above, riddled with generality and ambiguity.

If such law is allowed to pass, it will not only signal the death knell of the internet as a free marketplace of ideas in Australia, but it will signal to Australian citizens, and to citizens of the globe, that the Australian Government seeks total control of the dissemination of information within its borders.
